title: This week in game trailers: 'The Sims 4 University,' 'Secret Neighbor,' 'Pokémon,' 'Tangle Tower,' 'Moons of Madness'
text:
Discover what tests and treats await in "The Sims 4: Discover University," be surprised by a traitor in your midst in instant hit "Secret Neighbor," find out how a painting becomes prime suspect in the wonderful "Tangle Tower," go on a whistlestop tour of Pokémon visual history ahead of "Pokémon Sword & Shield" and get spooked by the creepy tentacle creatures of "Moons of Madness."

The Sims 4: Discover University



[Official Reveal Trailer: youtu.be/VtPy-71fkSc]

Continuing a franchise tradition -- the little computer people previously went to college in "The Sims 2: University" and "The Sims 3: University Life" -- with an expansion pack that brings enrolment, classes, collegiate experiences and extracurricular activities to the University of Britechester, or the Foxbury Institute. For Mac and PC from November 15, PlayStation 4 and Xbox One from December 17.

Secret Neighbor



[Launch Trailer: youtu.be/J5QIIQpnq08]

Previous game "Hello Neighbor" had players sneaking into a neighbor's house to find out the secrets of his basement. This one offers a clever twist -- you're one of six players doing the same, but this time one among your number is picking off everyone else as the Neighbor in disguise! Out now on PC (Steam, Xbox Store), Xbox One and Xbox Game Pass.

Tangle Tower



[Release Trailer: youtu.be/3JEliSJ859I]

Venture into this strange mystery and work out how a painted portrait ended up the prime suspect in a batty murder case, if such a thing is possible even in this surprising wonder. From the team behind "Detective Grimoire" (hence the similar quality of presentation). Out now for iOS (Apple Arcade), PC (Steam), and Nintendo Switch.

Pokémon Sword & Shield



[A new era of Pokémon begins: youtu.be/UMjKiC1l_yA]

This quick and intense blast of nostalgia and low-key video game tech history is even odder in an age of "Pokémon Go," where mobile devices literally superimpose Pokémon franchise creatures onto real-world backgrounds. Here, though, it's in service of emphasizing improvements in graphical wizardry over the course of the franchise's two-decade term, ahead of "Pokémon Sword and Shield" releasing for Nintendo Switch on November 15.

Moons of Madness



[Launch Trailer: youtu.be/8RPGUHMrjE0]

Cosmic horror overshadows a Mars research outpost, which has been collecting signals from some sort of intelligent life form, and an isolated engineer tries to survive long enough to find out what is really going on. Out now on PC, launching on PlayStation 4 and Xbox One in January 2020.
